ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class gives a great overview on the history, politics and economics behind the EU and Europe since the 1950s. It also provides a cool background on Brexit, The Eurozone Debt Crisis, trade and other current event issues.
Lots of knowledge about how the EU works, how it impacts the world, deeper understanding of Brexit/eurozone crisis
I learned the intricacies of the EU and became more familiar with the workings of the block.

I learned A TON of substantive knowledge about the EU, its history, politics and economics. In particular, this course covers Brexit, the Euro, the founding of the EU, and the Greek Sovereign Debt Crisis in great depth.
I gained the framework and knowledge needed to evaluate contemporary European economics, politics, and policies.
Learn a lot about a wide variety of topics crucial to the EU, from its inception to today
I learned so much about the EU and its systems. I have a much greater understanding of how international relations and bodies work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The guest lectures in the class were great, as well as the discussions and readings. I feel like we could have spent a little less time on logistics and could have gotten grades back a bit faster.

Strengths: Material and Marnix's teaching; getting to revise the policy memos definitely helped learning; great guest speakers; Weaknesses: we didn't get any indication of our grades until the day of the Cr/D deadline, would have been nice to get a bit more feedback on psets/first policy memo. Also not a huge fan of group work tbh but not a big deal, overall would still recommend this class if the material interests you! Also would suggest maybe adding a weekly canvas post assignment where people post questions/short observations about the readings so that more people stick with the readings.

This seminar was very engaging and there was no shortage of discussion, ever. Professor Amand is the real deal and is an expert on this topic. He was patient and creative, willing to entertain students ideas and re-explain confusing topics. The course does involve a lot of reading which improves your learning tremendously if you do it, but can sometimes be a bit more than manageable. The format of the final oral exam was also pretty intimidating and isnt necessarily a good fit for all types of students. Finally, Professor Amand didnt return any grades through the semester which can be difficult for some students, though he did let everyone know how they were generally doing before the Credit/D deadline. If youre excited to learn about the topic and engage with the class, it will be a fantastic experience.

The instructor was extremely knowledgable, passionate about the subject, and made the material extremely interesting with masterful storytelling. Readings were comprehensive and interesting without being overly burdensome. However, we did not really receive any feedback on our psets or second draft of memos.

S: The professor is an expert in his field. Also really enjoyed the guest lecturers. Discussion in class is great and the final (oral) really makes you understand the topics covered

W: Not as much feedback on the HW and Memos
This course is awesome! Professor Amand is the best and a huge strength of the course. The only weakness was a bit of a lack of feedback regarding how you were doing in the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Marnix is a great professor and in this class you will be able to look at the political, economic and other factors affecting European politics. It has a lot of application to other trade issues and current events as well.
Definitely!
Absolutely. Great class if this subject is of interest to you

Absolutely. This is a very engaging seminar if you are even remotely interested in economics or the EU. I was not well versed in EU politics, history or economics before the class and came away with a much better understanding. However, this class isnt a gut - you have to attend, participate and do the readings.
I would highly recommend it for the instructor alone! The EU will be an increasingly large player in the world, and not enough attention is being paid on the organizational body.
Definitely. If you have care or are interested in the EU for any reason even a little I would recommend this course
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It is a must take at Yale!
